Expires: March 4, 2019 Expires: March 12, 2019
DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance)
Extension For TLDs (Top Level Domains) Extension For TLDs (Top Level Domains)
draft-kitterman-dmarc-tld-00 draft-kitterman-dmarc-tld-00
Abstract Abstract
DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and
Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating
organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
DMARC [RFC7489] provides email sending organizational policy DMARC [RFC7489] provides email sending organizational policy
information to email receivers. Due to the design of DMARC [RFC7489] information to email receivers. Due to the design of DMARC [RFC7489]
and the nature of the Internet email architecture [RFC5598], there and the nature of the Internet email architecture [RFC5598], there
are interoperability issues associated with DMARC [RFC7489] are interoperability issues associated with DMARC [RFC7489]
deployment. These are discused in Interoperability Issues between deployment. These are discused in Interoperability Issues between
DMARC and Indirect Email Flows [RFC7960]. These issues are not DMARC and Indirect Email Flows [RFC7960]. These issues are not
applicable to TLDs, since they do not send mail. applicable to TLDs, since they do not send mail.
DMARC [RFC7489], by design, does not support requirements of TLD DMARC [RFC7489], by design, does not support requirements of TLD
operators. For TLDs that require use of DMARC [RFC7489], a subset of operators. For TLDs that require use of DMARC [RFC7489], a subset of
DMARC reporting and enforcement capability is needed for TLD DMARC reporting and enforcement capability is needed for TLD
operators to effectively manage and monitor implementation of TLD operators to effectively manage and monitor implementation of TLD
requirements. requirements.
Additionally, the ability to extend DMARC [RFC7489] policy to operate
against non-existent domains would enhance its utility for TLD
Operators as well as Domain Owners. Originally, DMARC [RFC7489]
included this functionality, but it was removed after significant
operational issues were discovered. This memo adds a new DMARC
[RFC7489] record tag to provide this capability on an optional, opt-
in basis.
2. Terminology and Definitions 2. Terminology and Definitions
This section defines terms used in the rest of the document. This section defines terms used in the rest of the document.
2.1. Conventions Used in This Document 2.1. Conventions Used in This Document
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and
"OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in
BCP 14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all BCP 14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all

2.2. Top Level Domain (TLD) 2.2. Top Level Domain (TLD)
The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in
numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names
starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain
names such as ".com" and ".us". names such as ".com" and ".us".
2.3. TLD Operator (TLDO) 2.3. TLD Operator (TLDO)
A TLD Operator manages operations within their TLD based on guidance A TLD Operator manages operations within their TLD.
and rules from ICANN (Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and
Numbers).
2.4. TLDO Controlled Domain Names 2.4. TLDO Controlled Domain Names
TLDO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by TLDO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by
TLDOs and not available for use as organizational domains (the term TLDOs and not available for use as organizational domains (the term
organizational domains is defined in DMARC [RFC7489]). Depending on organizational domains is defined in DMARC [RFC7489]). Depending on
TLD policy, these will have one (e.g. ".com") or more (e.g. ".co.uk") TLD policy, these will have one (e.g. ".com") or more (e.g. ".co.uk")
or more name components. name components.
2.5. Non-existent Domains
For DMARC [RFC7489] purposes, a non-existent domain is a domain name
that publishes none of A, AAAA, or MX records. This is a broader
definition than that in NXDOMAIN [RFC8020].
3. TLD DMARC Updates to DMARC Requirements 3. TLD DMARC Updates to DMARC Requirements
This document updates DMARC [RFC7489] as follows: This document updates DMARC [RFC7489] as follows:
3.1. General Updates 3.1. General Updates
References to "Domain Owners" also apply to TLDOs. References to "Domain Owners" also apply to TLDOs.
3.2. Section 6.1 DMARC Policy Record 3.2. Section 6.1 DMARC Policy Record
TLD DMARC records are published as a subdomain of the TLD. For the TLD DMARC records are published as a subdomain of the TLD. For the
TLD ".example", the TLDO would post DMARC preferences in a TXT record TLD ".example", the TLDO would post DMARC preferences in a TXT record
at "_dmarc.example". at "_dmarc.example".
3.3. Section 6.3. General Record Format 3.3. Section 6.5. Domain Owner Actions
The rf and ruf tags are not applicable to TLD DMARC and MUST be
ignored for TLD records.
3.4. Section 6.5. Domain Owner Actions
In addition to the DMARC [RFC7489] domain owner actions, TLDOs will In addition to the DMARC [RFC7489] domain owner actions, TLDOs will
need to update the "DMARC TLD Registry". See IANA Considerations need to update the "DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) Registry". This
below. registry is defined in Section 6.1.
3.5. Section 6.6.3. Policy Discovery 3.4. Section 6.6.3. Policy Discovery
A new step between step 3 and 4 is added: A new step between step 3 and 4 is added:
3A. If the set is now empty and the TLD of the Organizational Domain 3A. If the set is now empty and the TLD of the Organizational Domain
is listed in the DMARC TLD Registry, the Mail Receiver MUST query is listed in the DMARC TLD Registry, the Mail Receiver MUST query
the DNS for a DMARC TXT record at the DNS domain matching the TLD the DNS for a DMARC TXT record at the DNS domain matching the
in place of the RFC5322.From domain in the message (if different). Organizational Domain with one label removed in place of the
This record can contain policy to be asserted for subdomains of RFC5322.From domain in the message (if different). A possibly
the TLD. A possibly empty set of records is returned. empty set of records is returned.
3.6. 7.2. Aggregate Reports
NOTE: We would like to modify this section to allow multiple nxdomain
subdomain reports to be reported in a single report. This would also
require changes in the Appendix C XML schema. Recommend defering
this to discussion in the IETF DMARC working group where the authors
of the original design that disallows this can weigh in.
3.7. 7.3. Failure Reports
This section is not applicable to records identified via policy As an example, for a message with the Organizational Domain of
discovery step 3A. "example.compute.amazonaws.com.cn", the query for TLD DMARC would use
"_dmarc.compute.amazonaws.com.cn".
4. Non-existent Domain Requirements 4. Privacy Considerations
4.1. Section 6.3. General Record Format This document does not significantly change the Privacy
Considerations of [RFC7489].
A new "np" tag is added: 4.1. Feedback leakage to TLDO
np: Requested Mail Receiver policy for all non-existent domains With the exception of branded TLDs (e.g. ".google"), RUA and RUF
(plain-text; OPTIONAL). Indicates the policy to be enacted by the reports based on TLD DMARC have the potential to contain information
Receiver at the request of the Domain Owner. It applies only to about emails related to multiple organizations. As a result, privacy
subdomains of the domain queried and not to the domain itself. sensitive information might be leaked from a domain owning
Its syntax is identical to that of the "p" tag defined above. If organization to the TLDO.
absent, DMARC policy MUST NOT be applied for non-existent domains.
5. Privacy Considerations This is not an issue for organizational domains that publish DMARC
policy. For such domains, the feedback reporting addresses (RUA and
RUF) of the organization will be used. Since TLD DMARC is limited to
TLDs that mandate organizational domains publish DMARC policy, the
risk of this issue is limited to organizational domains that are out
of compliance with TLD policy.
This document does not change significantly change the Privacy TLDOs will receive feedback on non-existant domains, which may be
Considerations of [RFC7489]. Privacy considerations related to similar to existing organizational domains. Feedback related to such
Failure Reports do not apply to TLD DMARC. cousin domains have a small risk of carrying information related to
an actual organizational domain. To minimize this potential concern,
TLD DMARC feedback is best limited to Aggregate Reports. Feedback
Reports carry more detailed information and present a greater risk.

This section describes actions requested to be completed by IANA. This section describes actions requested to be completed by IANA.
7.1. DMARC Tag Registry Update 6.1. DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) Registry
IANA is requested to add the following item to the registry:

| Tag | Reference | Status | Description |
| Name | | | |
+--------+-----------+---------+------------------------------------+
| np | this | current | Requested handling policy for non- |
| | document | | existent domains |
+--------+-----------+---------+------------------------------------+
7.2. DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) Registry
IANA is requested to create a new DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD) IANA is requested to create a new DMARC Top Level Domain (TLD)
Registry within the Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, Registry within the Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting,
and Conformance (DMARC) Parameters Registry. and Conformance (DMARC) Parameters Registry.
Names of TLDs participating in TLD DMARC must be registered with IANA Names of TLDs participating in TLD DMARC must be registered with IANA
in this new sub-registry. New entries are assigned only for TLDs in this new sub-registry. New entries are assigned only for TLDs
that require use of DMARC. The requirement has to be documented in a that require use of DMARC. The requirement has to be documented in a
manner that satisfies the terms of Expert Review, per [RFC5226]. The manner that satisfies the terms of Expert Review, per [RFC5226]. The
Designated Expert needs to confirm that provided documentation Designated Expert needs to confirm that provided documentation
